density.note: Liquid ammonia at boiling point; requires refrigeration or pressure to maintain liquid state

specificHeat.note: Higher than water; excellent heat capacity

thermalConductivity.note: Decent thermal conductor for a liquid

latentHeatOfVaporization.note: High heat of vaporization; used as refrigerant because it absorbs heat when evaporating

evaporationCoefficient.note: Hertz-Knudsen α coefficient. Moderate-high - small molecule, some hydrogen bonding. Range 0.01-1.0.

latentHeatOfFusion.note: Energy required to melt frozen ammonia

electricalConductivity.note: Very poor conductor; liquid ammonia is nearly an insulator

antoineCoefficients.TminC_note: EMPIRICALLY VERIFIED RANGE MINIMUM: The Antoine coefficients were experimentally validated down to this temperature. Calculations below this are extrapolated (smooth curve continues, but accuracy may degrade).
antoineCoefficients.TmaxC_note: EMPIRICALLY VERIFIED RANGE MAXIMUM: The Antoine coefficients were experimentally validated up to this temperature. Calculations above this are extrapolated (smooth curve continues, but accuracy may degrade).
antoineCoefficients.source: Liquid ammonia vapor pressure from industrial refrigeration thermodynamic data; valid for cryogenic range (-77°C to 20°C).
antoineCoefficients.note: Ammonia only exists as liquid under refrigeration or pressure. Boiling point at 1 atm: -33.34°C. Essential for vapor pressure calculations in ammonia-based refrigeration systems.
